qas.question: What causes warping in vinyl records?

answers.text: heat, improper storage, exposure to sunlight, or manufacturing defects

qas.question: What is a cause of once per revolution pitch variation?

answers.text: warp, or from a spindle hole that was not precisely centered

qas.question: What method was used to protect a vinyl record?

answers.text: place the LP in a paper or plastic inner cover

qas.question: What were often found with a paper outter cover and no inner cover?
What happens if a vinyl comes with a bit of warp?

answers.text: A small degree of warp was common,

context: Vinyl records can be warped by <a0_0>heat, improper storage, exposure to sunlight, or manufacturing defects<a0_0/> such as excessively tight plastic shrinkwrap on the album cover. <a4_0>A small degree of warp was common,<a4_0/> and allowing for it was part of the art of turntable and tonearm design. "wow" (once-per-revolution pitch variation) could result from <a1_0>warp, or from a spindle hole that was not precisely centered<a1_0/>. Standard practice for LPs was to <a2_0>place the LP in a paper or plastic inner cover<a2_0/>. This, if placed within the outer cardboard cover so that the opening was entirely within the outer cover, was said to reduce ingress of dust onto the record surface. <a3_0>Singles<a3_0/>, with rare exceptions, had simple paper covers with no inner cover.
